sub_subject.name: Physical Geography (Earth Systems & Processes)
sub_subject.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Physical Geography (Earth Systems & Processes) (Geography)

objectives.objective_text: Identify living things (animals/plants) and non-living things (rocks/water).
Name the sun as what helps plants grow.
Identify a predator and prey.
Identify a forest, a desert, and the ice.
Name animals that live in the jungle.
Identify dirt as where plants grow.
Name worms as helpers in the soil.
Identify Humus (organic matter).
Identify a cliff and a cave.
Name an arch in the rock.
Identify a Spit (sand sticking out into water).
Identify waves crashing on the beach.
Name the sand and rocks on the shore.
Identify Longshore Drift (moving sand along the beach).
Identify an earthquake as the ground shaking.
Name 'Drop, Cover, and Hold On' as a safety rule.
Identify the epicenter and focus.
Identify that the ground can move.
Name Pangea as a time when all lands were connected.
Identify the 'Ring of Fire'.
Identify that the earth is a ball made of rock.
Name the ground we stand on as the 'Crust'.
Identify a volcano as a mountain that shoots fire and ash.
Name 'Lava' as hot rock that comes out.
Identify benefits of volcanoes (rich soil, new land).
Identify a flood as too much water on the land.
Name rain as a cause of floods.
Identify a dam as a way to control water.
Identify a waterfall.
Name a bend in the river.
Identify an Oxbow Lake from images of oxbow lake formation.
Identify a river flowing downhill.
Name the start (Source) and end (Mouth) of a river.
Identify a tributary (small river joining a big one).
Identify wind as moving air.
Name the sun as the heat source for the earth.
Identify the trade winds.
Identify rain, snow, and clouds.
Name the sun as what dries up puddles.
Identify Transpiration (plants releasing water).
Identify a storm with thunder and lightning.
Name a Tornado or Hurricane as a big wind.
Identify the 'Eye' of a hurricane.
Recall that animals need plants to eat.
Observe a food chain (Sun -> Grass -> Rabbit -> Fox).
Recall that different places have different plants.
Observe that camels live in hot places.
Recall that dirt can be different colors.
Observe sand, mud, and clay.
Recall that the sea makes shapes in the rock.
Observe a stack (rock standing alone in the sea).
Recall that the sea wears away the land.
Observe pebbles getting smooth.
Recall that earthquakes happen quickly.
Observe cracks in the ground in pictures.
Recall that mountains grow very slowly.
Observe that continents look like puzzle pieces.
Recall that it is very hot deep inside the earth.
Observe that rocks can be hard or crumbly.
Recall that volcanoes can be dangerous.
Observe pictures of an eruption.
Recall that floods can hurt houses.
Observe sandbags used to stop water.
Recall that rivers change the shape of the land.
Observe mud at the end of a river.
Recall that rivers can be fast or slow.
Observe stones in a river.
Recall that hot air goes up.
Observe clouds moving across the sky.
Recall that water goes up and comes down.
Observe images of the water cycle.
Recall that we stay inside during bad weather.
Observe weather warnings on TV.
Summarize the difference between Biotic and Abiotic factors.
Explain the role of a Producer, Consumer, and Decomposer.
Explain the concept of 'interdependence'.
Defend the resilience vs. fragility of different ecosystems.
Summarize the main characteristics of a Rainforest and a Desert.
Explain what 'Tundra' means (frozen ground).
Locate the Savanna (grassland with few trees).
Explain the concept of biodiversity.
Defend the importance of wetlands.
Summarize what soil is made of (rock bits, rotting plants, air, water).
Explain why farmers need good soil.
Explain the process of Leaching.
Defend the importance of soil conservation for civilization.
Summarize the sequence: Crack -> Cave -> Arch -> Stack -> Stump.
Explain how a beach is formed.
Explain the formation of a Tombolo or Bar.
Defend the classification of submergent (Fjords) vs emergent coastlines.
Summarize how waves are made by wind.
Explain Erosion (breaking) and Deposition (dropping).
Explain mass movement on cliffs (sliding/slumping).
Defend the dynamic equilibrium of coastal systems.
Summarize what causes an earthquake (plates getting stuck and slipping).
Explain what a seismograph does.
Explain the concept of liquefaction.
Defend the limitations of current prediction technology.
Summarize the idea of Continental Drift (Alfred Wegener).
Explain that plates bump into, pull apart, or slide past each other.
Explain the mechanism of 'Ridge Push' and 'Slab Pull'.
Defend the predictive power of tectonic theory.
Summarize the layers: Crust, Mantle, Outer Core, Inner Core.
Explain that the crust is broken into big puzzle pieces (plates).
Label a cross-section diagram of the earth.
Explain how we know what is inside the earth (seismic waves).
Defend the theory of a dynamic, changing earth.
Summarize how a volcano forms (magma rising).
Explain the difference between Magma (inside) and Lava (outside).
Explain the formation of a caldera.
Defend the classification of Hotspots (e.g., Hawaii) vs. boundary volcanoes.
Summarize why rivers overflow their banks.
Explain how trees help stop floods.
Defend the concept of 'Integrated Drainage Basin Management'.
Summarize how a waterfall is made (hard rock/soft rock).
Explain what a Meander is.
Explain the formation of levees.
Defend the transient nature of river features over geologic time.
Summarize the Upper, Middle, and Lower courses.
Explain that gravity makes water move.
Explain the concept of a drainage basin.
Defend the strategic importance of river mouths for cities.
Summarize why the equator is hot and poles are cold.
Explain that wind moves heat around the world.
Explain the Jet Stream.
Defend the impact of atmospheric circulation on human history (sailing routes).
Summarize Evaporation, Condensation, and Precipitation.
Explain 'Runoff' (water flowing on the ground).
Explain the difference between infiltration and percolation.
Defend the importance of the cryosphere (ice) in the cycle.
Summarize how a hurricane forms over warm water.
Explain the difference between a Watch and a Warning.
Explain the storm surge effect.
Defend the importance of preparation and building codes.
Compare a Food Chain with a Food Web.
Analyze the flow of energy through trophic levels.
Interpret the Nutrient Cycle (Gersmehl diagram - introductory).
Connect keystone species to ecosystem health.
Compare a Deciduous forest (leaves fall) with Coniferous (evergreen).
Analyze the relationship between climate and biome distribution.
Interpret a climate graph for a specific biome.
Connect the layers of the rainforest (Emergent, Canopy, Understory).
Compare sandy soil (drains fast) with clay soil (holds water).
Analyze a soil profile (O, A, B, C horizons).
Interpret the texture triangle (Sand, Silt, Clay).
Connect soil type to the vegetation it supports.
Compare a Headland (sticky out bit) with a Bay (curved in bit).
Analyze the formation of wave-cut platforms.
Interpret the conditions needed for sand dunes.
Connect rock hardness to coastline shape (discordant vs concordant).
Compare a sandy beach with a rocky cliff.
Analyze the difference between Constructive and Destructive waves.
Interpret the four types of erosion (Hydraulic action, Abrasion, Attrition, Solution).
Connect fetch size to wave energy.
Compare a small shake with a big destructive quake.
Analyze the Richter and Mercalli scales.
Interpret the difference between P-waves and S-waves.
Connect underwater earthquakes to Tsunamis.
Compare a Convergent boundary with a Divergent boundary.
Analyze the three types of plate margins (Destructive, Constructive, Conservative).
Interpret the formation of fold mountains (e.g., Himalayas).
Connect subduction zones to ocean trenches.
Compare the thin crust to the skin of an apple.
Analyze the difference between Lithosphere and Asthenosphere.
Interpret the state of matter in each layer (solid vs. molten).
Connect mantle convection currents to plate movement.
Compare an active volcano with a sleeping (dormant) one.
Analyze the difference between Shield and Composite volcanoes.
Interpret the risks of pyroclastic flows vs. lava flows.
Connect viscosity of magma to the explosiveness of the eruption.
Compare flash floods with slow floods.
Analyze a storm hydrograph (Lag time, Peak discharge).
Interpret the human causes of flooding (urbanization, deforestation).
Connect geology (permeable vs impermeable rock) to flood risk.
Compare a V-shaped valley with a flat floodplain.
Analyze the formation of gorges and rapids.
Interpret the processes of erosion (Hydraulic Action, Abrasion).
Connect deposition to the formation of deltas.
Compare a mountain stream (narrow/fast) with a big river (wide/slow).
Analyze how the cross-profile of a river changes downstream.
Interpret the Bradshaw Model (changes in velocity, discharge, load).
Connect the gradient to the energy of the river.
Compare high pressure (sunny) with low pressure (rainy).
Analyze the tri-cellular model (Hadley, Ferrel, Polar cells).
Interpret the Coriolis Effect (spinning earth turning winds).
Connect global circulation to the location of deserts.
Compare salt water in oceans with fresh water in rain.
Analyze the role of groundwater and aquifers.
Interpret the water cycle as a closed system.
Connect humidity to evaporation rates.
Compare a blizzard with a drought.
Analyze the conditions needed for tropical storms (27°C water, Coriolis).
Interpret the Saffir-Simpson scale.
Connect 'Tornado Alley' to US geography.
Evaluate the impact of removing a species from a web (Trophic Cascade).
Evaluate the fragility of the Tundra ecosystem.
Evaluate the causes of soil degradation (salinization, erosion).
Evaluate the formation of salt marshes behind spits.
Evaluate the impact of sub-aerial weathering on coastlines.
Evaluate earthquake-proof building designs.
Evaluate the evidence for plate tectonics (fossil correlation, paleomagnetism).
Evaluate the role of the magnetic field generated by the core.
Evaluate monitoring techniques used to predict eruptions.
Explain Hard vs. Soft engineering strategies.
Evaluate the cost-benefit of flood defenses.
Evaluate the formation of different delta types (Arcuate, Bird's foot).
Evaluate the factors affecting river discharge.
Evaluate the transfer of energy from equator to poles.
Evaluate the impact of urbanization on the water cycle (impermeable surfaces).
Evaluate the economic impact of extreme weather events.
Construct a diagram of the Carbon and Nitrogen cycles.
Synthesize the concept of 'carrying capacity'.
Construct a profile of the Chaparral/Mediterranean biome.
Synthesize the impact of latitude on vegetation belts.
Construct a description of soil formation factors (Parent material, Climate, Biota, Topography, Time).
Synthesize the relationship between bedrock and soil fertility.
Construct a field sketch of a coastal landscape.
Synthesize the life cycle of coastal features.
Construct a diagram of the sediment cell concept.
Synthesize the interaction between tides and coastal shape.
Construct a risk assessment for a specific fault line (e.g., San Andreas).
Synthesize the relationship between stress accumulation and release.
Construct a map showing major plate velocities and directions.
Synthesize tectonic history with biogeography.
Construct a detailed profile of the earth's internal composition.
Synthesize the relationship between internal heat and surface features.
Construct a case study of a major eruption (e.g., Mt. St. Helens or Pompeii).
Synthesize the global climate impact of supervolcanoes.
Construct a flood management plan for a specific river.
Synthesize the social and economic impacts of major flood events.
Construct a diagram of helicoidal flow in a meander.
Synthesize the impact of base level changes on river rejuvenation.
Construct a long profile diagram of a river.
Construct a diagram of global wind belts.
Synthesize the interaction between oceanic and atmospheric circulation.
Construct a diagram of the global hydrological cycle including storage times.
Synthesize the energy exchanges (latent heat) involved in phase changes.
Construct a tracking map of a historical storm.
Synthesize the relationship between climate change and storm intensity.
Synthesize the interaction between human engineering and natural flow.
